title: Judge Approves Request to Revamp Rogers Communications Board
summary: Media heir's plan to oust Rogers board members gets a Canadian judge's blessing. A Canadian judge approved a bid by Ed Rogers to reconstruct the board at Rogers Communications Inc., escalating a family feud for control of one of the country's largest telecommunications companies.

title: American Airlines Boosts Flight Attendants' Pay Ahead Holidays
summary: Flight attendants to earn as much as triple pay for holiday flights. American Airlines Group Inc. said it would pay flight attendants extra to work during peak holiday-travel periods as the carrier seeks to avoid staff shortfalls that contributed to more than 2,000 canceled flights last weekend and early this week.

title: Kellogg, Pfizer, Airbnb: Stocks That Defined the Week
summary: Here are seven major companies whose stocks moved on the week's news. Kellogg Co.

title: Durham Unravels the Russia Case
summary: His indictments reveal facts embarrassing to former special counsel Robert Mueller and the press.. Special counsel John Durham's latest indictment is an important step in unraveling what really happened in the long tale of false Russia-collusion allegations against the 2016 Trump presidential campaign. The facts in the indictment add to the evidence that this was from first to last a dirty trick by Hillary Clinton's campaign-and that the media were its gullible promoters.

title: The School Board Revolt
summary: Voters react to Covid restrictions and critical race theory in schools.. Glenn Youngkin's use of the education issue to win the Virginia Governor's race is getting most of the media attention, but less well known is that Tuesday saw a parental revolt against school boards in many parts of the country.

title: Behind the October Jobs Bump
summary: More people work when the feds stop paying them not to work.. The October job reports provides the first real snapshot of the labor market after the end of federal enhanced unemployment benefits. And what do you know? Job growth beat expectations for a change.

title: SEC Clears Path to Ban Foreign Companies From U.S. Exchanges
summary: The agency approved a rule that puts a framework in place to investigate auditing firms in jurisdictions such as China and Hong Kong. The Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday approved a rule aimed at implementing a law banning foreign companies from U.S. exchanges if their auditors haven't been inspected by American regulators.

title: New Yorkers Reject Schumer's Voting Ideas
summary: Voters say no to key planks in a Democratic election-reform bill.. Senate Democrats led by New York Sen. Chuck Schumer made another push this week to federalize elections under H.R.4, but they might want to check with the New Yorkers who on Tuesday defeated two ballot measures on voting.

title: Igor Danchenko Charged With Lying in Trump Dossier Probe
summary: Russia analyst is accused of misleading FBI about his relationship with Sergei Millian, who was president of the Russian-American Chamber of Commerce. A Russia analyst who fed information to the author of a salacious dossier about Donald Trump lied to federal investigators about his interactions with a business-group official he said was a source for the document, according to an indictment unsealed Thursday.

title: New York City Marathon App Embraces Hybrid
summary: For the first time this year, spectators can track virtual participants and runners pounding the NYC pavement. Like the workplace, the New York City Marathon has gone hybrid. For this first time this year, spectators will be able to track both virtual and in-person runners through an app developed by race sponsor Tata Consultancy Services Ltd.

title: Advent, Permira Near Deal to Buy McAfee for More Than $10 Billion
summary: A deal for the security-software company could be announced by Monday; talks are ongoing. Security-software company McAfee Corp. is nearing a deal to sell itself to a group including private-equity firms Advent International Corp. and Permira for more than $10 billion, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Opening Arguments in Arbery Slaying Case Begin
summary: Prosecution calls killing an attack based on faulty suspicions; defense argues men were protecting their neighborhood. The trial of the three white Georgia men charged in the murder of Ahmaud Arbery began Friday with prosecutors saying the unarmed Black man was the victim of trigger-happy vigilantes, and defense attorneys saying he was killed by men trained in law enforcement who were protecting a neighborhood beset by break-ins.

title: Rivian Automotive Boosts IPO Price Range
summary: Electric-vehicle maker now expects to sell shares at $72-$74 each. Rivian Automotive Inc. increased the expected price of its initial public offering on Friday, with one of the biggest deals of the year now eyeing a roughly $70 billion valuation.

title: Andrew Cuomo Arraignment Is Postponed Until January
summary: Former New York governor due in court Jan. 7, not Nov. 17, after prosecutors call filing against him 'potentially defective'. ALBANY, N. Y.-Prosecutors said the complaint against former New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo is "potentially defective" and successfully asked to push back his arraignment date in a letter filed with the court this week.

title: Is College Worth the Cost? That Depends
summary: A computer-science degree from Harvard usually pays off. Philosophy or gender studies, not so much.. College is expensive but worth it-or is it? College graduates generally make more money than those without a degree. But a closer look reveals that for many the benefit isn't spread equally, and a significant minority of students are worse off for having gone to college.

title: On Russiagate, Durham Indicts the Press Too
summary: His latest arrives just in time to expose a pathetic ABC News 'special' report on Christopher Steele.. It is the nature of any inquiry that more information is gained with the passage of time. Today's information is more complete than yesterday's. It affords better insight, deeper perspective and sounder judgment.

title: Biden Makes a Delaware-Size Land Grab in Utah
summary: He expands the size of two national monuments while ignoring the concerns of state and tribal leaders.. President Clinton took a drastic step in 1996 that changed Utah forever. Using the Antiquities Act of 1906, he unilaterally designated 1.7 million acres-a landmass larger than the state of Delaware-as a national monument. Done against the wishes of local leaders, Mr. Clinton's designation of the Grand Staircase National Monument had immediate negative effects, as it closed off the region to energy and resource development, including land that had previously produced funds for Utah's schools.

title: States Sue to Stop Biden Vaccine Mandate
summary: Lawsuits allege requirement is unconstitutional; White House says it has authority to issue rules. More than half of U.S. states are suing to stop the Biden administration from implementing new rules that require employers with more than 100 workers to ensure their employees are vaccinated against Covid-19 or get a weekly test.

title: The 'Hilarious' Unreality of Bidenomics
summary: The president casts his policies as shockingly effective; his energy secretary laughs at the idea of increasing U.S. oil supplies.. President Joe Biden took no questions from the media after making a statement in response to Friday morning's employment report from the Department of Labor. The report was encouraging, though not the titanic achievement he described. Perhaps he was hoping that his statement could somehow manage to speak for itself. Meanwhile the president's energy secretary, Jennifer Granholm, may be wishing she had said nothing at all in response to a question on gasoline prices and U.S. oil supply.

title: What to Read This Week
summary: The small town at the heart of America's first intellectual revolution, John Grisham's 'The Judge's List,' fashion and resistance in wartime Paris and more..

title: 'Hannah Arendt and Isaiah Berlin' Review: Clash of the Titans
summary: For Arendt and Berlin, it was a case of hate at first sight.. In the halcyon age before Covid, I caught a flight to a small town in Germany to see an opera about love between two philosophers. The love was not in the least bit Platonic. Hannah Arendt was 18 years old, fatherless, a virgin. Martin Heidegger was in his mid-30s, married with two sons, a leader in his field. In modern terms, the liaison was a classic #MeToo scenario, an abuse of trust and duty.

title: Leisure Travel Rebounds as Delta Variant Fades
summary: Vacationers are on the road again, lifting company sales and setting up a busy holiday travel season. Vacationers are returning to the roads and sky in the U.S. after an earlier pullback caused by the Delta variant, setting expectations for a busy holiday travel season.

title: Malibu Spec House With Hair Salon, Poker Room Asks $47.5 Million
summary: Resume Subscription. A Malibu spec house with an Apple Store-inspired glass staircase is listing for $47.5 million.

title: New Biden Vaccine Rules Don't Allow Self-Administered, Self-Reported Covid-19 Tests
summary: OSHA says requirement for oversight is to ensure integrity of result; some companies worry it creates new logistical challenge. Workers won't be allowed to both self-administer and self-report their Covid-19 tests to comply with new Biden administration requirements that mandate millions of employees get vaccinated or provide weekly test results.

title: Firefox Introduces Color Themes to Its Browser
summary: The new feature is an expansion of the company's redesign that rolled out earlier this year. Mozilla Corp.'s Firefox internet desktop browser is offering users a limited-time approach to color themes, updating a relatively small aspect of the user experience in an effort to make users feel more attached.

title: Resounding Success (Saturday Crossword, November 6)
Crazy Eights (Saturday Cryptic Puzzle, November 6)
Stocks Finish at New Highs After Jobs Data
summary: Monthly employment report showed pace of hiring picked up in October. U.S. stocks rose to fresh highs Friday and posted weekly gains after Labor Department data showed job growth rebounded in October following a summer slowdown.

title: Puerto Rico Oversight Board Files New Debt Plan
summary: The revised plan eliminates cuts to public-sector retiree benefits, but changes benefits for working teachers and judges. A federal board overseeing Puerto Rico's bankruptcy this week filed a new plan for restructuring the U.S. territory's debt that preserves pension benefits for retired public-sector employees, a point of contention that had threatened to derail the debt-restructuring deal.

title: Justice Department Probing Electric-Van Maker Workhorse
summary: Inquiry adds to an SEC probe and comes after the company changed management, suffered production setbacks. The Justice Department has opened an investigation into electric-van startup Workhorse Inc., according to documents reviewed by The Wall Street Journal.

title: U.S. Government Bond Yields Fall After Jobs Data
summary: Yield on 10-year note slides below 1.5%, extending a volatile week. U.S. government bonds rallied after a better-than-expected jobs report Friday, sending the yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note below 1.5% for the first time in about a month.

title: Inside JJ Redick's European-Inspired Brooklyn Penthouse, Which Just Hit the Market for $8.5 Million
summary: Resume Subscription. Former professional basketball player JJ Redick and his wife, Chelsea Redick, have listed their penthouse in Brooklyn for $8.5 million.

title: The Sounds of Silence
summary: John Cage's '4' 33"' was no compositional prank, but a deep exploration of the very nature of music and the beautiful chaos of life.

title: Colin Powell's Funeral Features Three U.S. Presidents
summary: Retired general, diplomat is remembered by former Secretary of State Madeleine Albright, who cites his 'unshakable commitment to his calling and word'. WASHINGTON-President Biden and two of his predecessors in the White House were among those who attended the funeral on Friday for Colin Powell, who served in top U.S. national-security roles and spent decades in the military.

title: Navy Removes Top Officers of Nuclear Sub After Underwater Crash
summary: USS Connecticut hit a structure some officials described as an undersea mountain while patrolling in the South China Sea last month. WASHINGTON-The U.S. Navy has removed the commander and other leaders of a submarine that struck an underwater mountain in the South China Sea last month, injuring nearly a dozen sailors.

title: Pfizer Says Covid-19 Pill Is 89% Effective in Study
summary: Drug company plans to seek FDA authorization of treatment for patients with a mild to moderate form of the illness. Pfizer Inc. said a preliminary look at study results found that its experimental pill was highly effective at preventing people at high risk of severe Covid-19 from needing hospitalization or dying, the latest encouraging performance for an early virus treatment.

title: Biden Administration to Cut Ties With Debt Collectors for Student Loans
summary: Switch to other contractors won't affect borrowers much for now due to pandemic-related freeze on payments. The U.S. Department of Education said it is ending its relationship with private collection agencies that had been tasked with recovering payments from federal student loan borrowers in default to improve collections and provide borrowers with more support.

title: Aaron Rodgers Attacks NFL and 'Woke Mob' in Defending His Unvaccinated Status
summary: The star quarterback, who had previously said he was "immunized," spoke out for the first time about his decision to not get vaccinated in an explosive interview. Green Bay Packers star quarterback Aaron Rodgers went on a sports talk show to assail both the National Football League and what he called the "woke mob" that has attacked him this week after he tested positive for Covid-19-an event that revealed he was unvaccinated despite publicly stating that he had been "immunized."

title: America Needs a Safety Net, Not a Hammock
summary: Congressional Democrats want to decouple welfare from work, undermining the American work ethic.. Americans are sympathetic and generous. They gave more than $470 billion to charity in 2020, according to the most recent Giving USA report. They also spend more than a billion hours every year volunteering for charitable organizations. But these amounts, large as they are, pale in comparison to the trillions of dollars in support taxpayers provide through various federal, state and local welfare programs. Americans want to help those who can't help themselves, or who are going through a rough patch. They don't want to support healthy adults and allow them to live off government welfare programs permanently. Americans believe in the safety net, not the safety hammock.

title: How AI Will Make Your Doctor Smarter
summary: From suicide prevention to infection tracking, the U.S. military is applying the latest technology to a host of medical challenges.. Hassan Tetteh has one of the coolest-sounding jobs in medicine. His official title is Warfighter Health Mission Chief for the Department of Defense Joint Artificial Intelligence Center. The Pentagon established the JAIC, or "Jake" as he pronounces it, in 2018 to ensure that America's combat operations don't fall behind rivals in using machine learning to enhance troop readiness, cybersecurity, joint maneuvers and "lethality."

title: U.S. Jobs Growth Rebounded Last Month
summary: Jobless rate fell to 4.6% as labor market bounces back from summer lull. The U.S. labor market sprang back to life in October after a summer slowdown, with employers briskly adding jobs and nearly 200,000 women joining the labor force.

title: Appeals Court Reinstates Convictions of Platinum Partners Executives
summary: Hedge fund founder Mark Nordlicht and co-chief investment officer David Levy were convicted in 2019 of securities fraud and other charges. A federal appeals court in New York on Friday restored the securities-fraud convictions of two executives of defunct hedge fund Platinum Partners.

title: Peter Paul Rubens Found Inspiration in Antiquity
summary: A new exhibition shows how the great painter was influenced by Greek myth and Roman art. A visitor to the Antwerp home of Peter Paul Rubens observed that it was full of Greek and Roman statues; the painter even worked while listening to an assistant read from the Roman historian Tacitus. Now "Rubens: Picturing Antiquity," an exhibition opening Nov. 10 at the Getty Villa in Los Angeles, shows just how much the classics helped to shape one of Europe's greatest artists.

title: Single-Family Rental Firms Eye Zillow's Housing Stock
summary: Interest comes as Zillow gets ready to shut down its home-flipping business. Big investment firms are looking at buying some of the thousands of homes that Zillow Group Inc. is preparing to unload as it dismantles its home-flipping business.

title: Kitchen Tips From the Chef Drew Barrymore Calls 'My Culinary Partner in Crime'
summary: With the new cookbook, 'Rebel Homemaker,' actress Drew Barrymore and her co-author and private chef Pilar Valdes lay out their accessible, appealing style of collaborating in the kitchen. Ms. Valdes invited us into her Brooklyn kitchen to share insider advice.. Three years ago, actress Drew Barrymore found herself at a crossroads. Newly divorced, at the end of her Netflix series "Santa Clarita Diet," she was a Californian newly transplanted to New York, trying to get her daughter into kindergarten. As it happened, chef Pilar Valdes was at a similar transition point. After working in nonprofits for almost a decade, she had started Kickshaw Cookery, initially a membership lunch-delivery service, with a friend. When her business partner moved out of state, Ms. Valdes started thinking about the future of Kickshaw-by then also a catering company-and began working with Ms. Barrymore, first as a chef and later as a regular guest on CBS's "The Drew Barrymore Show."

title: Airbus CEO Jean Pierson Put the Heat on Boeing
summary: Frenchman, who has died at age 80, was an uninhibited salesman as the European aircraft maker caught up with American rivals. Jean Pierson, who served as chief executive of Airbus from 1985 to 1998, proved a star salesman for the European airplane maker as it began catching up with Boeing Co. in a global market once dominated by American manufacturers.

title: The Risks and Rewards of Angel Investing
summary: The risk is straightforward: You very well could lose all your money. But you could possibly make a lot of money, and have fun while doing it.. It isn't easy being an angel.

title: A Closer Look
summary: Selections from 'Tales of Fearless Girls: Forgotten Stories from Around the World' by Isabel Otter, illustrated by Ana Sender. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: 'The Transcendentalists and Their World' Review: Concord's Second Revolution
summary: How a generation of American writers took inspiration from Ralph Waldo Emerson's provocative, irresistible ideas.. It is a remarkable fact that American transcendentalism's two best-known authors-Ralph Waldo Emerson and Henry David Thoreau-lived within walking distance in the same small village of 2,000 souls. Like the Renaissance London of Shakespeare and Marlowe or the mid-20th-century Liverpool of Lennon and McCartney, antebellum Concord, Mass., was a surprising hub of genius, a confluence of talent that defies easy explanation.

title: 'Everything and Less' Review: Fiction in Prime Time
summary: Amazon has transformed the way we read books-and, according to Mark McGurl, how they're written.. Early in his study "Everything and Less: The Novel in the Age of Amazon , " Stanford professor and literary critic Mark McGurl points out that the wealthiest novelist of all time is not J.K. Rowling or James Patterson or any other habitual mega-bestseller, but MacKenzie Scott, the author of two modestly well-received works of literary fiction and, incidentally, the billionaire ex-wife of Jeff Bezos. The statement, in Mr. McGurl's usual fashion, is as provocative as it is casually asserted. On one hand, it has the virtue of being technically true, lending credence to Mr. McGurl's argument that Amazon is overturning the way we understand books, changing them at a molecular level from works of art into monetizable products. On the other hand, the claim is based on an accidental correlation: Ms. Scott is rich, but not from her writing. It happens, in fact, that Napoleon Bonaparte too once wrote a novel. If I were to say that he was therefore the most famous novelist in world history, would I be making an interesting point or engaging in semantic deception?

title: Mysteries: John Grisham's 'The Judge's List'
summary: A suspect sitting behind the bench is at the heart of the 37th thriller from the author of 'The Firm.'. Political thrillers written by political figures have become their own subgenre, even if the results are often less than thrilling. But when a recent American presidential nominee writes a book with Canada's most beloved mystery author, attention is due. Hence we have "State of Terror," a gripping collaboration between Hillary Rodham Clinton and Louise Penny.

title: 'Miss Dior' Review: A Brother's Fashion, a Sister's Heroism
summary: Catherine Dior spent the years of Occupation taking risks-and paying a heavy price.. On July 6, 1944, as she rode her bicycle near Paris's Place du Trocadéro, Christian Dior's younger sister was arrested by the Gestapo. Four armed thugs took her to an apartment, where she was brutally tortured before being sent to Ravensbrück, Germany's notorious women's concentration camp. Catherine, aged 26, was an active member of the French Resistance. For the next nine months, Christian, who at the time was working as a designer for the couturier Lucien Lelong, had no idea whether his sister was dead or alive.

title: Former NHL Player Mike Green Lists Washington, D.C., Home for $3.495 Million
summary: Green played for the Washington Capitals from 2005 to 2015. Former professional hockey player Mike Green is selling his Washington, D.C., mansion for $3.495 million.

title: There Are No Free Lunches in Climate Politics
summary: At big summits, leaders try to devise the most indirect means to reach vaguely defined objectives.. Is anyone surprised that international climate politics is no different from domestic climate politics? ("The Climate Summit to Nowhere," Review & Outlook, Oct. 30). In developed nations, people profess to desire drastic emissions cuts-so long as they don't have to pay for them. Large majorities believe climate change to be a concern. Yet only a little more than half of Americans say they would pay an extra $1 a month to fight it and even fewer, 28%, would pay $10 a month.

title: John Musgrave Helps Vietnam Veterans Find Their Way Home
summary: A Marine turned war protester and poet reckons with his experiences in a new memoir. As a wounded Marine convalescing at Quantico Naval Hospital in 1968, John Musgrave felt moved to write his first poem. Having eagerly joined the Marine Corps fresh out of his Kansas high school in 1966, he assumed he would write about the heroism of fighting in Vietnam. But as he recounts in his new memoir, "The Education of Corporal John Musgrave," published this week, he instead found himself assuming the perspective of a 16-year-old pregnant widow burying her 18-year-old Marine husband: "Over his corpse was laid the flag/a worthless red, white, and blue rag."

title: Economists Don't Know What Will End Inflation
summary: Past experience suggests experts and policy makers should be humble.. Mickey Levy is correct that inflation is a bigger problem than the Federal Reserve realizes ("Fed Complacency Feeds Inflation," op-ed, Nov. 1). But subduing inflation is likely to be more difficult than he and others suggest.

title: The Joys of Keeping Score Are Not Forgotten
summary: Bob Greene brings back fond memories-and precise details-from days at the ballpark.. Bob Greene's op-ed "Dime Scorecards Were Worth Something" (Oct. 27) brought back fond memories. My friends and I used to lean our unlocked bikes against the first base wall of Wrigley Field, get a hot dog with all the trimmings, sneak under the turnstiles and sit behind first base. In those days, there were very few Cubs fans. We meticulously kept score in case the umpire lost track and needed to check the count or the score.

title: Biden Leaves Us at a Loss for Words
summary: The three things I most admire about him are. . .. Apropos of Peggy Noonan's "Can Slidin' Biden Regain His Footing?" (Declarations, Oct. 30), we have an observation from a recent essay by playwright David Mamet. "Who, however liberal, could complete this sentence: 'The three things I most admire about Joe Biden are . . .'? Even the staunchest Democrat must attempt a response beginning with "Uh . . ."

title: Don't Use Colin Powell to Make the Case for Systemic Racism
summary: The theory's assumptions are contradicted emphatically by the facts of his life.. A letter in reply to Peggy Noonan argues that we should ask if America is "still producing the ignorant and bigoted people who tried to stop" Colin Powell's rise (Oct. 30). The writer assumes Powell had to overcome racial bias in his climb to the top of the Army. Yet in his autobiography, Powell writes that he and other black officers "had joined the most democratic institution in America, where they could rise or fall on merit." He experienced discrimination in the South, but not on base. "I regarded military installations in the South as healthy cells in an otherwise sick body," he wrote.

title: 'Burning Boy' Review: Stephen Crane's Low Life
summary: Never concerned about respectability, the journalist and novelist took his subjects (and his pleasures) where he found them.. Paul Auster has written some unexpected books before now-a homage to his manual typewriter, for one; a tale told from the perspective of a dog, for another-but none so surprising as this one. "Burning Boy" is an almost 800-page walking tour through the life and work of Stephen Crane (1871-1900). The life was short but the art was long. Although he is mostly remembered for his brief novel of the Civil War, "The Red Badge of Courage" (1895), Crane's collected fiction, nonfiction and poetry fill 10 volumes. He died in June 1900 at the age of 28, having edged his way into a century in which his impressionistic prose would have fared better than it did in the era of W.D. Howells and Hamlin Garland (both of whom helped him). By then Crane was domiciled in England, where he counted H.G. Wells and Joseph Conrad among his friends-novelists who straddle the old age and the new, as Crane himself had promised to do.

title: Children's Books: Tales of Wonder and Wisdom
summary: New collections and revisions open a trove of stories for children from sources familiar and fresh.. Once upon a time, people told fairy tales because-well, there were lots of reasons. Folklorists believe that some stories got their start as anecdotes that were spun over time into such good yarns that people couldn't resist passing them on. Some began as funny or scary incidents in the lives of specific men and women who, over time, lost their proper names and became the stuff of legend. And some stories, such as the one about Little Red Riding Hood, have their origins so far back in the misty past that we do not know how they began.

title: Fed's Powell and Brainard Met With Biden at White House
summary: President Biden is expected to decide soon on who will lead Federal Reserve. WASHINGTON-President Biden held separate meetings with Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell and Fed governor Lael Brainard at the White House on Thursday, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Levy Proposed to Shrink Shipping Industry's Carbon Footprint
summary: International Maritime Organization considers charging ship owners $100 for every ton of carbon dioxide emitted from vessels. LONDON-The International Maritime Organization is mulling a new tax on shipping to help build a global network of alternative fuel stations for vessels and subsidize developing countries facing higher export costs.

title: Science Fiction: Adrian Tchaikovsky's 'Elder Race'
summary: The epic tale of a land ruled by magic-or the sober record of a world colonized by science?. Adrian Tchaikovsky's "Elder Race" recounts how Lynesse Fourth Daughter of the Royal Line of Lannesite climbed to the Tower of Nyrgoth Elder, last of the sorcerers, to call for his aid against the demons overrunning the land.

title: Thunberg Leads Climate Protest, Criticizing COP26 Talks
summary: Swedish climate campaigner has hardened her stance against the U.N. summit. GLASGOW-Organizers of the COP26 United Nations climate summit welcomed one of their highest-profile critics Friday: Greta Thunberg.

title: Blinken Details New Steps in 'Havana Syndrome' Response
summary: Biden administration steps up efforts to get at causes, effects of mysterious neurological illnesses. Secretary of State Antony Blinken on Friday announced additional steps in the State Department's response to mysterious health incidents among U.S. diplomats and relatives, including new leadership, increased access to treatment and efforts to understand and prevent the incidents.

title: The Browns Cut Odell Beckham Jr. The Divorce Began on Social Media.
summary: LeBron James tweeted "#FreeOBJ." Beckham's dad posted a video blasting Cleveland's quarterback. A few days later, the team got rid of the polarizing superstar.. A famous and influential Ohioan went on social media Tuesday and shared his thoughts about a certain Cleveland Browns receiver who was beginning to hint that he wasn't exactly happy with the team.

title: Fake News Release Claims Kroger to Accept Bitcoin Cash
summary: Supermarket operator says release, which was posted to its investor relations' page, should be disregarded. A news release went up on Kroger Inc.'s website Friday saying customers would soon be able to use Bitcoin Cash as payment in its stores and online. It wasn't true, the grocer said.

title: Is Facebook Bad for You? It Is for About 360 Million Users, Company Surveys Suggest
summary: Resume Subscription. Facebook researchers have found that 1 in 8 of its users report engaging in compulsive use of social media that impacts their sleep, work, parenting or relationships, according to documents reviewed by The Wall Street Journal.

title: A Driving Tour of the Scottish Highlands Fit for Royalty
summary: Rural Scotland, a longtime royal playground, is drawing uncrowned sybarites too these days, in search of luxurious hotels, wild beauty and a wee bit of whisky. AS THE grandson of a Scotswoman, I've always instinctively loved Scotland. All my previous trips to the country-first during my penniless junior year abroad, then later as a travel writer-bolstered my enthusiasm. I invariably met locals up for a wee chat and often a wee drop of whisky, too, and came away awed by its landscapes and fascinated by its history. But aside from a few notable exceptions, like Gleneagles, famous for its three golf courses, I mostly slept in austere lodgings and dined on wholesome but plain food. For all its homespun charms and exultant natural beauty, Scotland never registered with me as a luxury destination. Then again, in 1852, Queen Victoria and Prince Albert, also smitten by the scenery, bought Balmoral Castle in what's now Cairngorms National Park, clearly appreciating the area's potential as a cosseting retreat.

title: Hot-and-Cold Jobs Market Still Far From Full
summary: The job market appears tight in many ways, but for the Fed there is still plenty of underlying slack. Federal Reserve policy makers have made clear they don't think the economy is close to full employment yet. When might it be?

title: Donald Trump's Ageless Advice for Mark Zuckerberg
summary: As Facebook becomes Meta, its leader may want to ponder something the former president said back in 1987. Back in Business is an occasional column that puts the present day in perspective by looking at business history and those who shaped it. Read previous installments of the column here.

title: Should You Invest With Fund Managers Who Have Lots of Experience?
summary: Longer-tenure fund managers are more reliable than rookies, but hit fewer home runs, research shows. Fund investors often debate: Should I entrust my money to an experienced fund manager with a record over many different market cycles, or should I go with an upstart manager who might have fresh ideas on how to generate gains?

title: How the Rock Concert Changed America
summary: Resume Subscription. Seventy years ago, in the fall of 1951, a white Los Angeles disc jockey named Hunter Hancock hosted a series of rhythm & blues concerts that foreshadowed the modern rock concert. They were held at midnight at the city's Olympic Auditorium, a 10,000-seat venue that stood at the intersection of several ethnic neighborhoods and was used mostly as a boxing and professional wrestling arena.

title: Why Home Buyers Should Comparison Shop for Mortgage Rates-but Don't
summary: Even a small difference among interest-rate offerings can add up to noticeable savings. Scott Baker is an associate professor of finance at Northwestern University's Kellogg School of Management.

title: U.S. Ends Pandemic Drug, Vaccine Contract With Emergent
summary: The agreement was terminated after Emergent encountered problems making Covid-19 vaccines. The federal government and Emergent BioSolutions Inc. terminated a pandemic-preparedness contract after the contract drug manufacturer experienced problems manufacturing Covid-19 vaccines.

title: With New OSHA Rules, Expect More High-Paying Jobs to Require Covid-19 Vaccine
summary: Growing share of open positions publicizing rules for shots signals potential new normal in hiring process, experts say. People looking for work in a tight job market are increasingly finding employers requiring vaccination against Covid-19, with a small but growing percentage flagging those rules to prospective hires from the outset.

title: Democrats Push Fix for Green-Card Logjam in Social-Spending Bill
summary: Tucked into the $1.85 trillion package is a proposal to recover unused slots and make them available. WASHINGTON-Immigrants caught in yearslong green-card backlogs could become permanent residents in the U.S. much faster because of a little-noticed immigration provision tucked into Democrats' $1.85 trillion social-spending and climate package.

title: Square's Future Needs to Take Shape
summary: Without the tailwind of stimulus checks, Square has to see some of its longer-term moves start to pay off. Square 's area greatly expanded during the depths of the pandemic. Now it needs to fill in that space.

title: Driverless 'Robotaxis' Arrive at the Stock Market
summary: Newly listed shares of Aurora Innovation will be a key gauge of investor interest in autonomous vehicles, particularly for private peers Waymo, Cruise and Argo AI. Driverless vehicles have a new public face: Aurora Innovation . Its stock will be a barometer of investor sentiment toward a technology that seems likely to change the world, albeit slowly.

title: Covid-19 Certificates Look Likely to Linger in Europe
summary: Winter surge in infections is pushing governments across the continent to extend rules requiring proof of immunity for many activities. PARIS-The passes that restrict access to restaurants, gyms and many other venues across Europe were supposed to be transitory, but with the specter of a winter resurgence of Covid-19 infections, they look likely to stay, at least until next year.

title: New Galápagos Conservation Efforts Aim to Counter China Fishing Fleet
summary: Environmentalists applaud plan by Ecuador and others to create a vast area off-limits to industrial fishing, but enforcement will be hard. But enforcement is likely to be a challenge.

The cut-glass dish or silver platter that graced the table twice a year, with compartments tailor-made for stacks of crisp carrot spears and frilly celery sticks, sunny deviled eggs, piles of briny piccalilli, pickled beets and peppery radishes?

summary: From Peru to the Philippines, bad harvests and supply bottlenecks are leaving poor families hungry. Now, she says, with the price of meat and other foods up by 30%, she often goes to bed hungry so there will be enough rice and beans for her four children.

title: Auschwitz Tattoo-Kit Auction Fuels Debate in Israel
summary: Tel Aviv court suspends the Nov. 9 sale after complaint from Holocaust survivors group. title: Twelve Ways to Wear Chic Pieces This Fall
summary: Bold new ideas for how to dress after dark, with pieces that are just as powerful in the light of day.. Photographer Jeano Edwards and stylist Chloe Grace Press photographed models Baba Chogwu and Temitope Ajayi at the gardens of the Monkey Island Estate hotel, which is situated on a private island in England's River Thames. Using a monochrome palette, Press created pared-back ensembles that are super-luxe and work for daytime or after dark. A soft gray Miu Miu dress, a matching top and skirt by Versace or a classic white Salvatore Ferragamo coat exude a sense of ease. A knit Bottega Veneta one-shoulder dress offers a striking silhouette while a silky, cream-colored top from Fendi shows skin with ladylike chic. Stroll through gardens on balmier days in an open-weave Valentino gown. The dressed-up style of a Celine by Hedi Slimane dress, complete with Paula Rowan gloves and a Chanel bracelet, turns out to be the perfect outfit for a boat ride-ditto a furry vest from Saint Laurent by Anthony Vaccarello. -Jessica Gibbs

title: 'Clean' and 'Natural' Beauty Products: Real Thing or Marketing Ploy?
summary: In this skeptic's guide to clean beauty, we answer 6 common questions about the trend. Up first: What do buzzwords like 'toxin-free' and 'all-natural' even mean?. IF I COULD "Supermarket Sweep" through any store, it would be Sephora: I imagine grabbing heaps of chubby Nars highlighter sticks, Pat McGrath glitter and enough Jo Malone London perfume to make me smell like a sprawling English garden. This fantasy has its flaws, being neither environmentally friendly nor financially feasible, but beauty products have always been an indulgence for me. As a child in the 1980s, I lived to poke around in my aunt's nail-polish drawer; more recently, I've relished unsheathing my preferred Chanel Michèle lipstick. There was no fretting over ingredients or worries about hidden evils. Lately, however, cosmetics have grown complicated and makeup has become a minefield, thanks to the steady rise of "clean beauty."
